The U.S. appears to be in a serious ongoing information war with Russian intelligence and the Putin administration.  According to various reports, it seems that Putin and Russian intelligence are using multiple types of approaches to divide Americans, and create discord and internal hostility in our society. Putin, his oligarchs and Russian intelligence seem to have significant inside help in doing this. This inside help appears to include Facebook, Twitter and social media as well as friends of Putin and his associates within American society and the U.S. government.  As more Americans understand the reality and seriousness of these penetrations into American society and the USG, there will probably be increased concern here at home. And, possibly some kind of effective and successful U.S. countermeasures can be implemented. President Trump and President Putin met at the G20 Summit , but neither party has extended an invitation to their counterpart to date. given the Russia investigation by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, recent diplomat expulsions, and the rising tensions of North Korea, neither politician could afford the political backlash of holding an official bi-lateral visit. IT would be too risky for Trump, raising eyebrows and Putin has no PR to gain from a meeting.

The probability of such an event is diminished to nearly nothing given the short period of time left before the deadline and the length of time generally required to set up such formal events. Given the lack of any discussion of a bilateral meeting and no evidence of an existing invitation, the chances would seem extremely slim.  In March 2017, a bilateral visit between President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China was formally announced in only 12 days, between Secretary of State Rex Tillerson’s Beijing visit on March 18th and the formal announcement on March 30th, which was noted to be an extremely quick turnaround. The meeting did not take place until roughly a week later. Even if a similarly unprecedented timeline might be forecast for a potential meeting between Trump and Putin, there is no chatter about an upcoming trip for Secretary Tillerson to Moscow (he was last in Russia in April), which would likely be a catalyst for such a bilateral meeting to occur.  Trump already has a bilateral meeting scheduled this week with Malaysia's Prime Minister. Particularly with the recent devastation due to multiple hurricanes hitting the southeastern United States, it is unlikely Trump will make a trip abroad this month for any multilateral meetings (none are so far announced), and therefore he will be unlikely to set in motion the process of inviting Putin to the White House before October 1, 2017, or of being invited to the Kremlin.

Chances of such a bilateral official visit seem to be diminishing due to various circumstances. In light of the expulsion of U.S. diplomats from Russian, the likelihood of diplomatic meetings would, at the surface, seem to be diminished.  But, the effect of POTUS signing the new Russian sanctions bill may in fact spur discussion over how to better handle the relationship between the two countries.  I admit, that consequence seems unlikely to manifest, particularly with the Trump-Russia issues that permeate every facet of U.S. politics these days.  That being considered, Trump has an incentive - maintaining a semblance of credibility and deniability in the face of U.S. media - to avoid direct interaction with Russia at all costs if it has any potential to be construed as favoring Russia.  On the other hand, Putin would seem to have a small incentive to engage with the U.S. given both these new sanctions and the Pentagon's recent indication that it was prepared to get involved in Ukraine in some capacity.  Add in Russia's planned military exercises on NATO boarders, and you have a situation that is ripe for disaster and also prime for discussion.  Thus, although Trump would lose political capital by reaching out, Putin would not and would stand to gain in the eyes of the international community bu reaching out before any military action (exercises or otherwise) came to bear.  For these reasons, I believe there is a slight, but unlikely, chance that a bilateral visit could occur.

The entire Trump-Putin "bromance" was all an offgrowth of an offhand remark by Trump in primary season that Putin was a stronger leader than Obama.  This is a story that sort of fueled itself due to Trump's penchant for doubling down on controversy.  It made more sense in primary season than in the current climate. That doesn't mean a talk is unlikely, just that the current bid of 75% seems too high for something where he has little to gain, while for Putin Trump can remain too much a loose cannon for there to be a driving force for such a meeting.  I would see multilateral talks over an issue like Syria to be far more likely, and to somewhat obviate the need for a bilateral talk. Finally, I think a lot of people have misunderstood trump's ploy of trying to make European NATO members come closer to compliance with their treaty obligations for defense spending.  A bilateral talk goes too far.  I think we see with the Australian refugee kerfuffle that Trump likes to complain, but he's not trying to burn bridges (yet).

Dropping after Trump did not reduce sanctions on Russia and added sanctions on Russian Ally Iran. On Thursday, the Trump administration modified sanctions issued against Russia during the Obama administration. The Treasury Department released a license permitting certain technology-related transactions between U.S. companies and the Federal Security Service of Russia. The sanctions were initially put in place in December 2016 following reports from the national intelligence community that Russia had used cyberattacks to influence the presidential election. White House press secretary Sean Spicer rejected characterizations of the license as an easing of sanctions. He said, “The Treasury Department — from what I understand, it is a fairly common practice for the Treasury Department, after sanctions are put in place, to go back and to look at whether or not there needs to be specific carve-outs for different either industries or products and services that need to be going back and forth.”

Instead, I'm starting to think Trump may be a very anti-travel president. He's barely left the White House since coming into office. He just made a trip to Delaware in secret and cancelled a trip to Wisconsin. There are no foreign trips planned on the horizon.  When he finally does travel, Russia can't be his FIRST stop. So he'll have to go somewhere else first. Canada, Mexico, the UK and Israel would usually be at the top of any president's list, but there might be a few issues with some of those countries you've heard about. For all forecasting this question, please note: 1.  An Official Visit is when high-ranking officials (cabinet level to head of government) are invited to visit another country by its government. Honors are given if the foreign official is the head of government, but not so for cabinet-rank officials. No luncheon or dinner is required. The host country pays for the visit’s cost for the official delegation unless the delegation opts to provide for its own needs.  In this type of visit, the visiting official may have up to six (not counting the official) personnel as part of his official delegation. 2.  A Bilateral Meeting is a meeting between two head of state (or other high-ranking officials) meet on the margins of a summit. E.G.;  President Barack Obama met with President Xi Jinping of China for a bilateral meeting on the margins of the G20 Leaders Summit in Hangzhou, China.  The two heads of state exchanged views on a range of global, regional, and bilateral subjects.   3.  A State Visit is when a foreign head of state visits, having been invited by the host head of state. Arrival ceremonies include the playing of the national anthems of the two nations, a review of the honor guards, and rendering of full military honors, including a 21-gun salute for the head of state. I am delighted by the healthy skepticism that you fellow forecasters are showing regarding truthfulness, provenance and intentionality of the FBI’s Grizzly Steppe report https://www.us-cert.gov/sites/default/files/publications/JAR_16-20296A_GRIZZLY%20STEPPE-2016-1229.pdf; the Office of the  Director of National Intelligence’s report on Russian attacks on the 2016 Presidential election, https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/ICA_2017_01.pdf;  and the, ahem, “Goldengate” report https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3259984-Trump-Intelligence-Allegations.html Hypothesis: Why might it be that U.S. CIA analysts (reportedly) performed significantly worse than Good Judgment Project forecasters, despite forming a shadow team that competed on the same questions but with access also to classified information? http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2014/04/02/297839429/-so-you-think-youre-smarter-than-a-cia-agent. My hypothesis: they were being actively mislead by their sources of classified information. Here is a start at either supporting or falsifying that hypothesis. Comparison class: Post 9-11, intelligence that Iraq had not dismantled its weapons of mass destruction programs. There were some elements of active deception by both the Saddam Hussein regime and anti-regime forces such as Ahmad Chalabi. Hussein’s strategy was to keep his enemies uncertain of his regime’s capabilities. Chalabi’s motivation was to get the U.S. to put him into power in place of Hussein. Anti-comparison class #1: Advances in psychology outside the published scientific literature are making major gains on the Big Lie and other persuasion techniques pioneered in the 20th Century.  Anti-comparison example: use of Cambridge Analytica by the Trump team to surgically target a winning basket of electoral college votes despite losing the popular vote by ~2.8M. https://cambridgeanalytica.org/. They also provided psychographic message targeting for the successful Brexit "Leave" campaign Anti-comparison class #2: Today the science and technology underlying these sorts of disinformation campaigns is evolving fast. IMHO, the most important challenge facing intelligence professionals is the dynamics of computationally-based disinformation and how to fold in human forecasters in such a way as to provide them with the best possible data sources. Anti-comparison example: Brexit. Pundits, polls, betting markets, Gjopen and even the Good Judgment, Inc. superforecaster team were all predicting a Remain win, with a high degree of confidence. Only the Websays.com hybrid forecasting system (working with the SENSEI Consortium) was successful, likely because it used humans in the loop along with machine learning to filter out computational propaganda scripting attacks. Indeed, their final three days of forecasting pegged Leave’s final vote share at 51.79% vs the final election result of 51.9%. One likely contributing factor to the failings of human forecasters: a recent research note published at https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.06356 reports heavy bot activity in the Brexit campaign. This problem of computational propaganda scripting attacks also has been documented and analyzed by recent and current research funded by DARPA’s Twitter Bot Challenge, and the U.S. National Science Foundation’s Division of Social and Economic Sciences, which analyzed bot activity in the Brexit campaigns and U.S. Presidential campaign. (www.politicalbots.org)   Other citations for the disinformation environment: 
Germany sees rise in Russian propaganda, cyber attacks 
http://in.reuters.com/article/germany-russia-idINKBN13X16C
Russia hackers: German spy chief Kahl warns of election disruption
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-38142968
The Lauded Russian Hacker Whose Company Landed on the U.S. Blacklist
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/31/world/europe/russia-hacking-alisa-shevchenko.html
How a Putin Fan Overseas Pushed Pro-Trump Propaganda to Americans
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/17/world/europe/russia-propaganda-elections.html
The Perfect Weapon: How Russian Cyberpower Invaded the U.S.
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/13/us/politics/russia-hack-election-dnc.html OTOH, there appear to be elements of sloppy reporting and poor methodology in evaluating the disinformation environment:
http://www.nationalreview.com/article/442291/buzzfeed-facebook-fake-news-study-methodology-questioned
http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-propaganda-about-russian-propaganda Action item: Please, you folks, tell me, what do you suggest might be some next steps in determining whether we can support or falsify the hypothesis:  Are the U.S. intelligence services significantly being mislead by their classified data sources? Why this is important: our Republic may be endangered, perhaps fatally, if we can’t figure out how to function in face of the rapidly evolving forces of disinformation.

Cases of the one country hosting the other for bilateral summits are not that common, relative to discussions that occur in the contexts of other meetings or in other locations. Other's confidence that it will occur rises my prior somewhat, but looking at the reasons causes me to discount many of them, particularly the most confident. People cite a single report by the Sunday times that was later refuted, even though the supposed trip does not even meet the question criteria. Others cite completely irrelevant facts such as their personal dislike of Putin or Trump, or even their fear that liberalism is dying. There is the case that Obama did cancel a planned trip in the past, so there are plenty of reasons for the countries to meet. Despite the surrounding geopolitical circumstances being largely similar if not worse, Trump's lack of concern for international norms suggests some possibility. However, Trump is still in a democracy, Putin is still in a dictatorship, and Snowden is still in Moscow. Just admiring another leader isn't grounds for a meeting and the facts on the ground haven't changed. There are opportunities to meet without one side hosting the other, such as the G20 this year. Given the surrounding circumstances, it seems prudent to keep meetings more low-key, at least for the moment.

The probability of Trump or Putin hosting each other for a bilateral conference is equal to the probability of Trump hosting Putin plus the probability of Putin hosting Trump plus the probability of both hosting each other before October 2017. Then it just comes down to estimating probabilities, and I claim no special knowledge here. I put the probability of Trump hosting Putin at .12 because of the hostile political climate toward Russia in the US right now, especially surrounding Trump. I put the probability of Putin hosting Trump as slightly higher at .30 because I imagine that Russia and Putin would feel important and macho being the host of a bilateral conference with Trump and Trump would likewise feel flattered and somewhat eager to defy political advisers and public opinion. I keep this probability relatively low because October 2017 is a short time-frame. I have the probability of both hosting each other as a product of the former two probabilities. This comes out to .42.

"There was absolutely no effect on the outcome of the election including the fact that there was no tampering whatsoever with voting machines," Trump said. Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence who was briefed on the report on Friday, took issue with Trump's comments.  "The President-Elect’s statement that the Russian hacking had 'absolutely no effect on the outcome of the election' is not supported by the briefing, report, or common sense," Schiff said.  "It is one thing to say that there was no tampering with vote tallying - which is true - it is another thing to say that the daily dumping of documents disparaging to ... Clinton that was made possible by Russian cyber operations had no effect on the campaigns," he said. "The consequence of these disclosures was hugely beneficial to the President-Elect and damaging to the Clinton campaign, just as the Russians intended."
Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr, a North Carolina Republican, said his panel would continue to compile "facts surrounding Russia's active measures," adding: "This is a troubling chapter in an ongoing story."

As far as I can tell, since 2000, the US has hosted 8 bilateral visits from Russian Presidents (Putin 2000, 2001, 2003, 2005, 2007, Medvedev 2009 & 2010, Putin 2015 ... Medvedev also attended group summits in 2011 and 2012 and Puting one in 2004). That implies an average of 1 bilateral Russian Presidential visit every 2.1 years. Source: https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/visits/russia Alternatively, focusing on Putin only - he has made 6 bilateral visits to the US in his 13 years as President (2000, 2001, 2003, 2005, 2007, 2015), i.e. excluding the May 2008-May 2012 period when Medvedev was President. (the 2000 visit is not from wiki link but from the previous link from US department of history).  This implies an average of 1 visit every 2.2 years. source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_presidential_trips_made_by_Vladimir_Putin.  The above two data points imply a Russian President visit to the US occurs once every c. 2.1 years.  Now how likely is it for the US President to visit Russia? According to wiki, the likelihood is 1 visit every 2 years on average, going back to 1993 (12 visits over 24 years). Clinton had 5 visits, Bush 6 and Obama 1 (in 2009, I don't believe there was a bilateral meeting during the 2013 G20 summit). source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_the_President_of_the_United_States Simply adding these probabilities together would yield a c. 47% chance of Russia visiting US and a c. 50% chance of US visiting Russia, so a combined c. 97%. But this is lazy thinking because in practice, in some years, there was a both a visit to the US and one to Russia. In fact, going back 24 years to 1993, there have been 16 years with a bilateral meeting of the two Presidents, and 8 with no meeting - i.e. an a-priori probability of 67%. However, I start with a higher probability than this due to:
- Obama and Russia clearly had a colder relationship (3 meetings in 8 years) than previous presidents (13 meetings in 16 years), and indeed than it seems Trump is keen to engender a closer relationship
- Using the ex-Obama period implies a starting probability of 81% (13 out of 16)
- The fact Trump will likely want to start his presidency showing that he means business by having a high-profile meeting with Putin in my eyes raises the probability even further (perhaps 10-15%)
- However, the question ends on 1 October 2017, which cuts out 3 months of the year. I therefore drop the likelihood a little for this (perhaps 5-7%) Combining the above, I start at a likelihood of 88%.

Updating from 10% thanks to comments by @elc13 [1]. 1. BASE RATES
A lot of my previous analysis started from base rates of presidential visits to *any* country. If we look at visits by/to just Russia, the base rate is different. For the greatest possible specificity, I will look only at official state visits to/from Russia upon inauguration of a new American president (i.e. reelection doesn't count). I will also restrict to post-1991, since arguably pre-1991 it was a whole different ball game and not so representative of the present. Three new presidents were inaugurated since then: Clinton in 1993, Bush in 2001, Obama in 2009. Of these, only Obama officially state visited Russia before Oct of his first year. That suggests a base rate of 33% for before-Oct meetings. If we want to get more precise, the first official visit between Russia & USA (in either direction) after a new American president was inaugurated took place: (i) 12 months after inauguration for Clinton;
(ii) 10 months in for Bush; and
(iii) 5.5 months in for Obama. This small dataset makes for an average of 9.2 and a standard deviation of 2.7; if we assume a normal distribution with these parameters, that makes for a 37% chance of the delay being < 8.3 months (necessary for occurrence before 1 Oct 2017). That's reassuringly close maybe? Let's call the base rate 35%. 2. OTHER MEETINGS
I also looked more closely at other opportunities Trump & Putin would have to meet, outside of an official state visit. As it happens, Clinton, Bush and Obama all met with Russian leadership in non-state, multilateral meetings, before official state visits happened: (i) Clinton 3 times, the first being 10 months before first official visit;
(ii) Bush twice, the first being 5 months before first official visit; and
(iii) Obama once, 2 months before first official visit. Looking through Wikipedia [2,3] I tried to find systematic such opportunities for Trump & Putin to meet. The big obvious ones are the G-20 and G-8 summits. There are also APEC summits and various UN gatherings. The next G-20 meeting will be 7-8 July 2017. An official state visit would have to happen 2.7 months after that for the question to resolve positively. As it turns out, Russia is currently banned from the G-8 until further notice, due to the Ukraine situation. Next year the G-8 (currently G-7) will discuss conditions for Russia's return [4] but that will be after the question period has ended. As far as I can tell, the only UN meeting attended by Russian presidents (Medvedev & Putin) is the UN General Assembly. That's always in mid-September though, so unlikely to form the basis of a pre-October state visit. Finally, APEC summits since 2005 almost always happen in mid-November, with a couple exceptions in early September. Also seems unlikely to serve as basis of a pre-October state visit. 3. PUTIN IT TOGETHER
As I mentioned in my previous forecast, there are at least 3 sources of real tension between USA and Russia: (i) Ukraine; (ii) Snowden; (iii) Syria. Then we have the fact that only the G-20 meeting could provide a first Putin/Trump meeting. None of the last 3 American presidents have made or hosted a "blind" Russian state visit (i.e. w/o meeting elsewhere first). The G-20 meeting would only allow a 2.7 month window, about as short as Obama's window, and the Obama administration had a whole thing about "resetting" the relationship with Russia [5]. Conflicts (i)-(iii) make me think the window between G-20 meeting and official state visit should be longer than the norm. I think it's fair to say relations with Russia are as bad as they've been since Clinton? All this makes me want to more than halve the base rate, from 35% down to 15%. Finally, it could happen that an official state visit takes place for no other reason than for Trump & Putin to show off. Nothing gets accomplished, etc. I can't rule this out, let's give it a 10% chance. Total odds: 25%. [1] http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/388501
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_Vladimir_Putin
[3] https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0_%D0%9C%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0 (in Russian)
[4] https://sputniknews.com/politics/201604101037767850-russia-g8-return-debate/

As I write this the consensus is at 80% yes, which seems wildly optimistic to me. Scrolling down a few pages I notice 80-90% of forecasts offer no supporting reasoning. About half of the ones that do offer reasoning are based purely on things Trump said, and do not cite any historical precedent. As some have noted below, the base rate for presidential visits to places is low; recent  presidents usually travel 10-20 times a year [1], and at least half of these is to attend meetings and summits, hence don't count as state visits. If we forget geopolitics and simply assume that there are ~50 countries the president could visit, this suggests a 10%-20% chance the president would "state visit" any given country in their first year. From the other end, state visits by foreign leaders to the USA are also rare. Wikipedia has a list [2] which drives home the point that there is a dizzying variety of types of visit, and official state visits are the minority. Under the "Europe" section --- which could be argued is the section most representative of Russia --- I counted 45 "state visits" and 71 "official visits". To reiterate, that is a total of 116 official/state visits for the entire continent of Europe since (depending on the country) WW1 / WW2 / the founding of the relevant country. Again forgetting geopolitics, if we say there are ~30 countries, that's ~4 official/state visits per country since WW2, or roughly 1 every 18 years, implying a probability of ~6% per year. For comparison, there have been 4 official/state visits from Russia since 1992, implying a rate of 1 every 6 years. However for Russia the visits are heavily skewed toward the past, in the few years after the collapse of the USSR. So the base rate for this question is something like (10% to 20%) + 6% ~ 20%. I can think of several reasons to drive this number down, and very few to drive it up. Driving it down, we have (i) Russian invasion of Ukraine, which the US dislikes, and has approved sanctions against; (ii) Russia providing asylum to Snowden, which the US strongly disapproves, Republicans most of all; (iii) Russia and US are on opposite sides of Syrian conflict. This means US-Russia relations are very strained, and only a minority of official/state visits are to countries with which relations are strained. Driving it up, we have (iv) Russia is a major power, and it is a priority to manage relations with it; (v) Trump said some nice things about Putin during the campaign; (vi) there are rumors that Trump has been in touch with Putin. I think base rates and (i)-(iii) will play the determining role in this question.  Note the difference between (i)-(iii) and (v)-(vi); (i)-(iii) are things that ACTUALLY HAPPENED, whereas (v)-(vi) are simply things people said. My general view is that talk is cheap. Trump hasn't even taken office yet and has already reneged on major campaign points (prosecuting Hillary, torturing terrorists). I think (iv) is an actual thing too, but I'm not sure official state visits are ever the first recourse toward normalizing strained relations. I find it more likely that Trump and Putin will feel each other out at summits and whatnot before committing to official state visits. Finally, some people are saying Trump could go for it because it would be an easy foreign policy win for him early in his presidency. But what kind of deal could he "easily" strike with Putin re Syria / Snowden? Only one where he gave Putin most of what he asks for. If I try to imagine that actually happening, I easily see his opponents painting such a deal as Trump being weak and caving to Putin. I don't think he wants that. On balance I'm tempted to adjust from the base rate of 20% down to 5% because of (i)-(iii) and up to 7% because of (iv)-(vi). But the deadline is far, so from general uncertainty I'll bump it up to 10%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_the_President_of_the_United_States
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_and_government_visits_to_the_United_States

Anwar Sadat in 1981 and Vicente Fox in 2001.] Russia has had two state visits: One in 1992 and one in 1994. That is an average of about once every 17 years since 1992 for about a 5% chance in any given year. Notably there have been none in over 20 years.  So, for Putin visiting the US on an official state visit I am putting it at about 3%. This is factoring in that base rates are skewed by near post-independence visits and that there is a lower base rate for inauguration years. The outside view is that Trump and Putin seem to get along better than do most US and Russian presidents. Given how rare state visits are, however, I don’t give the outside view much weight at all. I am assuming the same probability for Trump going to Russia for no reason other than I have not had time to check out any relevant base rates, but I suspect they will also surprise me on the down side. The outside view on that is that Trump's ego may be too big to not be the host in that scenario. Again, almost no weight assigned to that outside view.  For now I am starting with 6%. Note: Yes, going back to 1980 is a random starting point. I just wanted a decent sample size and ran out of time to collect data.
